qas.question: The government planned to evacuate 1.4 million from which city?
What trial took place on August 10 1939?
How long were lights not allowed on after dark?
What was most unpopular affect of the war with civilians ?
Why did the government  and civil service not want to relocate during the war?

context: The government planned to voluntarily evacuate four million people—mostly women and children—from urban areas, including 1.4 million from <a0_0>London<a0_0/>. It expected about 90% of evacuees to stay in private homes, and conducted an extensive survey to determine available space. Detailed preparations for transporting them were developed. A trial blackout was held on 10 August 1939, and when Germany invaded Poland on 1 September <a1_0>a blackout<a1_0/> began at sunset. Lights would not be allowed after dark for <a2_0>almost six years<a2_0/>, and <a3_0>the blackout<a3_0/> became by far the most unpopular aspect of the war for civilians, more than rationing.:51,106 The relocation of the government and the civil service was also planned, but would only have occurred if necessary so as not to <a4_0>damage civilian morale<a4_0/>.:33
